results.title: Everybody rides the carousel. Parts 1-3
results.creator_credit: John Hubley, Faith Hubley, Hubley Studios and Pyramid Films
results.brief_description: A view of Erik H. Erikson’s “Eight stages of life”. A whimsical, power-packed animated film that depicts life as a carousel with eight horses representing the up-down, push-pull, positive-negative aspects of each of the eight stages.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Hubley, Faith Hubley, Hubley Studios and Pyramid Films

results.title: Exercise green!
results.creator_credit: Philip Bond, Terry Ohlsson and Kingcroft Productions
results.brief_description: A simulated full scale military, naval and air force assault exercise from planning through victualling, sappers’ engineering, parachuting and shelling followed by a computer analysis of the entire operation.

results.title: Exercise Beats Arthritis
results.brief_description: Regular exercise helps you to gain some control over your arthritis and take responsibility for yourself. Working with this video, you can begin to plan your own exercise program, building exercise and activity into your daily life. Learn how to relax too, so you can release built-up tension and calm your mind. Valerie Sayce is a physiotherapist who specialises in exercise programs for people with arthritis. She works at the Arthritis Foundation of Victoria as a Physical Activities educator.

results.title: Every square inch
results.creator_credit: Ross McConnell and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Every square inch of Canada, second largest country in the world, has been put on maps, and much of it is being mapped again, even more thoroughly. How such a vast territory is committed to paper is seen in this film, stage by stage: aerial photography; ground surveying with sophisticated instruments and at headquarters, the exacting work of translating, plotting, and printing.

results.title: Exchange and divide
results.creator_credit: Margaret Dickinson, Donna Grey and British Film Institute
results.brief_description: Kenneth Carr, a young executive in a multinational company, is facing the prospect of divorce. The audience is invited to become involved with him and to participate in a story centred around his emotional and sexual life. This expectation is frustrated when Kenneth’s solicitor jumps out of his fictional role and, adopting the manner of a neutral, authoritative expert, invites the audience instead to absorb useful facts. These are mainly to do with family law and finance; the Carr’s marriage is treated as convenient case history. The solicitor’s account is supplemented by various images and by short interventions from people connected with the couple. These are introduced as if their purpose was illustrative but rather than reinforce his words, they begin to contradict them and to offer alternative interpretations. Through the couple, interest is focused on the complexities of a hierarchy determined both by class and sex.

results.title: Every second car
results.creator_credit: Patricia Burwash, Rex Tasker, Wolf Koenig and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Every second car now on the road, it is estimated, will cause an injury-producing accident during its lifetime. But, according to experts on safety promotion interviewed in this film, the driver is less to blame than is commonly supposed. Why so many injuries occur is illustrated in experimental crashes; how safety engineering could reduce traffic casualties is shown in a number of test vehicles.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Patricia Burwash, Rex Tasker, Wolf Koenig and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Even the smallest change is a victory (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Gary Bictel, Joy Johnson and Lance Evoy
results.brief_description: Seven high school students discuss the inferior status of women and their limited rights in comparison to men. They question the ways in which men control, dominate and express themselves through competition and aggression. The group feels these existing attitudes must change.

results.title: Every dog's guide to complete home safety
results.creator_credit: Les Drew, Douglas MacDonald, William Pettigrew and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Hilarious animated film communicates over forty safety tips for homes with infants and young children. The film’s hero is a very earnest, somewhat pompous, but endearing dog called Wally. A “professional” in home safety, Wally is assigned to a house with an infant whose parents have little safety consciousness. Accidents and near-accidents succeed each other with lightning speed, constantly putting Wally to the test. This comic film will help viewers of all ages become “home-safety smart.” For parents, babysitters, and the elementary school classroom. Music by Eldon Rathburn. Also available on DVD [319319].

results.title: Every child = Chaque enfant
results.creator_credit: Eugene Fedorenko, Derek Lamb and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Produced at the invitation of the United Nations Organisation to celebrate UNICEF’s Declaration of Children’s Rights, this film is the Canadaian contribution to the hour-long feature film consisting of ten six-minute segments in celebration of the Year of the Child. This six minute segment illustrates one of the ten Principles of the Declaration, namely that every child is entitled to a name and a nationality. It is the story of a baby who appears mysteriously on the door of a busy executive, and who is subsequently bounced from household to household down the block. Nobody in the community is interested in caring for the baby without a name. (Twelve awards, icluding: Ottawa, Varna, Milan, Oscar) Also available on DVD [319319].
